Text saved: Lewis wants to see the number of sea protected areas in the world go up from 3% to 10%. He hopes this will help to stop the harm caused by things people do, such as too much fishing, making the water dirty, and leaving rubbish. On his trips, Lewis has seen this harm to nature himself. For example, he has swum over **coral**, which is a hard, colourful material made by small sea animals, that has lost its colour because the water got hotter. He has also seen places under the not-deep waters of the Red Sea that have no living things and are covered with plastic. Lewis believes that nature can get better if it has enough space to do so. However, time is running out. He says that if we do not start looking after our seas, we may soon have a problem that we cannot fix.

Text saved: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3% to 10% in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He has swum over **coral**, which is a hard, colourful material made by small sea animals, that has lost its colour because the water got hotter, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, with no life and covered with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.

Text saved: Lewis wants to see more marine protected areas in the world. He would like the number to increase from 3% to 10%. This is to stop the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, polluting, and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental damage first-hand. He has swum over **coral**, which is a hard, colourful material made by small sea animals. This coral has lost its colour because the water got hotter. He also saw underwater deserts beneath the not deep waters of the Red Sea. These places had no life and were covered with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have a problem we cannot fix on our hands.
